stream_context.summary: Kaze programmed the boss fight for Course 15, a corrupted 'pentapus' Yoshi. The stream focused on implementing the tentacle attack that emerges from portals, including its spline-based collision, animation, and the addition of a light beam as a visual cue for the player. He also outlined the full gameplay loop for the fight and reacted to a community-made PC port of one of his older hacks.

development_findings.summary: The Course 15 boss is a 'pentapose' (a five-tentacled creature), a design choice originating from Kaze's desire to create a creature with a non-standard number of tentacles.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking, how come there's only octopuses? Why is there no septapose or hexapose or pentapose or tetrapose? You know what I mean? So we made a pentapose.

development_findings.summary: The boss fight gameplay loop involves dodging tentacle attacks, destroying weak points ('wards') on the tentacles to make the boss's head vulnerable, and then attacking a primary weak point on its nose to inflict damage.
development_findings.quote: The loop is basically, Yoshi is like floating around here... tentacles come and attack and the tentacles have these wards on them... you jump on his tentacle, you destroy the ward and then Yoshi gets weak. And his head goes down... you're going up there and you punch the ward and that's dealing damage to him.

development_findings.summary: The tentacle's hit detection is being implemented using spline-based collision, a more complex method suited for its dynamic, curving shape.
development_findings.quote: This one is gonna be a spline collision, and I'm just gonna have to make it so that if Mario's in spline, he takes damage.

development_findings.summary: Kaze collaborated with a community member, Akumoid, to create an advanced reflection shader for level geometry, demonstrating a willingness to incorporate external technical help.
development_findings.quote: The last few days, a person called Akumoid has been DMing with me. They wanted to learn about N64 shaders and they wanted to help me make a good shader for this. And together we came up with this one here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes an accurate unofficial PC port of RTYI is highly improbable due to the sheer volume of custom code that standard porting tools and methods cannot replicate.
development_findings.quote: If someone ported Return to Yoshi's Island I doubt they would even get like close to getting it right because there's so much custom code.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning to embed encrypted messages within the boss's dialogue, creating a hidden layer of mystery for players to solve.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking for the yoshi boss here we're actually using some cryptographic messages that we sent the player through his text boxes.

development_findings.summary: The game will feature nine boss fights in its main courses, compared to the original Super Mario 64's six.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally avoids discussing politics to leverage the psychological 'halo effect,' believing that ambiguity makes him more likable to a broader audience.
context_findings.quote: If no one knows what my political beliefs are, then people are more likely to assume my political beliefs overlap with theirs and they will like me for it. So I think it's better to just not talk about or not make any controversial political statements.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a personal philosophy valuing semantic precision, wishing people could only use words they could scientifically or logically define.
context_findings.quote: I had a dream one time that people were not able to say words unless they could describe exactly what they mean... I feel like if we lived in a world like that our lives would be so much better.

context_findings.summary: Kaze maintains a strict hands-off policy regarding fan-made ports or modifications of his work, permitting them only if the creators are fully self-sufficient.
context_findings.quote: My general policy is if you can do it on yourself without my help, you can do with my hacks whatever you want. But as soon as you start asking me for help, I'm gonna be annoyed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals a past prank of hiding lewd 3D models in unused game maps, visible only to other ROM hackers who opened his files, showcasing a mischievous side.
context_findings.quote: I would import the 3D model of a large cock into Castle Grounds. And not use Castle Grounds on my hack... as soon as you use a ROM hacking tool to open my hack, you would just see a large cock. And I thought it was the funniest thing ever.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for the common greeting 'How are you doing?', finding it simultaneously polite and irritating.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided the concept art for the Course 15 pentapus boss, which Kaze is using as the basis for the placeholder model and programming.
biobak.quote: This is the concept that Biobak has sent me.

biobak.summary: Kaze's current 3D model for the boss is a functional placeholder intended to communicate the design goals and mechanics to Biobak, who will create the final asset.
biobak.quote: The textures on the boss are not final, though. They're more like a symbolic representation of what I want this to look like, so that when Biowake remakes my model, he knows what I was going for.

badub.summary: Badub's music is gaining enough recognition that a fan commented on him becoming 'royalty,' suggesting his reputation is growing within the community.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for building the outside area of Course 13. Kaze notes that this work has been ongoing for a while and is one of the last major pieces for that level.
zeina.quote: Course 13 is missing the outside area. Zeina wanted to work on that, she's been working on it for a long time now... they're basically like both 95% done.

key_stories.title: Solving the Unseen Attack
key_stories.summary: To solve the problem of unfair off-screen attacks from a new boss, Kaze designed and implemented a system of portals and light beams. After several iterations to fix visibility and rendering issues, he created an effective visual cue that prioritizes fair gameplay over perfect aesthetics.
key_stories.challenge: The boss's tentacle attacks could spawn anywhere, including off-screen, making them unfair and impossible for the player to see coming and react to.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided a visual warning was necessary. He first added a portal, then a light effect. He debugged the light being too faint and then fixed a render distance issue preventing it from being seen from behind. He iterated on the light's shape and animation timing to balance visibility and aesthetics.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a bright light cone that grows from the portal before the tentacle emerges. This visual cue is visible from all angles, even behind the player, effectively warning them of an impending attack at the cost of some visual polish.
key_stories.key_quote: The whole point we ended the light... we need this to exist to be able to tell what's going on.

key_stories.title: The Unofficial Port Critique
key_stories.summary: Kaze critically reviewed a community-made PC port of another one of his hacks. While giving credit for the effort, his detailed analysis revealed that core custom-coded mechanics were broken, reaffirming his stance that his complex projects can't be easily or accurately ported by others.
key_stories.challenge: A community member shared a video of an unofficial PC port of Kaze's hack, "Peach's Fury." Kaze, skeptical due to past poor attempts, decided to investigate its quality live on stream.
key_stories.process: Kaze first viewed an old, non-functional version of the port. After being directed to a newer video, he performed a detailed analysis, crediting what was ported correctly (basic movement) while identifying major flaws (missing water, broken trampolines, non-functional key level mechanics).
key_stories.outcome: He found the port to be more advanced than expected but still fundamentally broken, with incorrect rendering and missing custom gameplay features like the carousel. The exercise reinforced his belief that his heavily customized hacks cannot be properly ported by the community, especially RTYI.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, it's clearly very rough around the edges... but yeah I see if someone ported Return to Yoshi's Island I doubt they would even get like close to getting it right because there's so much custom code.
